awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Software Platform for the Assessment and Measurement of Port Disruptions
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project may enable stakeholders to model the functional and economic impact of cross-organizational, inter-infrastructure disruptions to intermodal supply chain movements.  The project directly addresses the need for more resilient supply chains.  Just-in-time supply chains designed for efficiency can result in high-impact disruptions and motivate the need for stakeholders to understand economic losses on disruptions via secondary, operational effects on intermodal transportation networks. Planning tools for resilient supply chain movements should employ holistic threat models that enable stakeholders to consider tradeoffs between infrastructure complexity and operational efficiencies.  The algorithms and envisioned software platform will help stakeholders to apply emerging threats to their infrastructure, quantify potential impacts, and strategically invest for increased community resilience.

This I-Corps project integrates discrete-event simulation and network flow optimization to compute optimal, cost-minimizing vehicle and commodity flows through shipping ports.  The simulation also reroutes goods based on non-linear costs and economic impacts.  This optimization algorithm enhances the capabilities to capture capacity constraints and to model delays resulting from disrupted commodity movements.  Routing vehicles and commodities is a non-deterministic polynomial-time hardness problem.  Existing approaches use time-expanded networks to model commodity movements, but they result in scalability issues for large practical instances.  The proposed optimizer adopts a dynamic approach to model discrete times and introduces delay nodes and arcs to accommodate container movements.  The proposed optimizer also constrains per-unit-time flow rates of commodities (e.g. road capacity, crane rate) in a continuous-time framework, thus significantly enhancing scalability.  The tool both estimates costs due to disruptions and finds least cost ways to effectively recover from or mitigate their impacts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
At the conclusion of the cohort, the team did not find product-market fit and a startup was not formed. Given, however, the importance of supply-chain disruptions in the recent news, we have continued to conduct technology transition activities and will continue to investigate the formation of a startup or licensing opportunity.

Pilot studies: We discovered that several of the stakeholders, such as port captains and tenants are very interested in our software tool, and would like to quantify their disruption costs on historical data. The team has proposed that we conduct pilot studies on representative instances which will allow us to demonstrate scalability of our approach on highly granular datasets.

PI research focus:
The PI's research focus has broadened to include mitigation measures for cyber-physical disruptions prior to such disruption events, and robust planning to counter the future costs of cyber-attacks. In our interviews we discovered that future customers will see value from such work and will therefore continue to expand the capabilities of our existing tool to make it more versatile. New methodological advancements will be required to achieve this goal, but we plan to pursue both technology transition activities and building the new technology in parallel.

PI integrate lean startup methodologies into classroom:
The PI's experience with the NSF I-Corps program helps her bring a unique perspective into the classroom (both graduate and undergraduate) and into Senior Design projects she advises. For graduate students, it helps her bring a perspective on designing research by observing and speaking with operators on the field -- in turn helping the graduate students understand that research does not operate in isolation from real-world problems and are indeed motivated by such problems. The experience of the I-Corps also helps the PI design effective teaching tools for the Systems Engineering and Design program as well as the Industrial Engineering program at her institution.   

EL employment offer based on I-Corps:
Following the NSF I-Corps, EL Weaver accepted a position at Idaho National Laboratory (INL) as a Senior Critical Infrastructure Analyst.  Although this position did not directly result from I-Corps, the ability to integrate a Lean Startup Methodology into a research program provides a unique skillset for this applied research environment. EL Weaver is permitted, via INL, to continue to work on tech transition for the Port Disruptions Tool and commercialize it via an explicit conflict of interest management plan.  Moreover, the I-Corps curriculum greatly informed an overall approach to writing research proposals and conference papers in which research contributions are explicitly mapped to hypothesized value propositions for one or more customer segments.  Such an approach has been adopted in several ongoing projects at INL.


Last Modified: 06/09/2022
Modified by: Lavanya Marla
